Title: the pulled groin extrapolation

Scene: The apartment. Amy is staring into space.
Outside Howard’s house. Amy rings the bell.
The apartment. Sheldon is playing with his train set.
Howard’s bedroom. Howard is playing with a lightsabre.
The stairwell. Amy is helping Leonard up the stairs.
Leonard: Who wants the last dumpling?
Aren’t you going with Sheldon?
Oh. Well, I have some work to do, so…
Okay. Wouldn’t you be more comfortable at home?
All righty then. Guess I’ll just get started.
Amy?
You okay?
I thought you were reading.
I, I’m fine.
What, who told you that?
Well, you stay as long as you’d like.
It was good, good. Just out of curiosity, what time do you usually go to bed?
Not really. Is that my yearbook?
Well, it wasn’t spray-painting a lightning bolt on my briefcase, I can tell you that.
Aw.
Rough night, Casey Jones?
What’s in the bag?
Ah, sure. That’d be nice.
Wouldn’t you rather bring Sheldon?
Ready.
Amy, this is for you.
No, thank you. I’m really not much of a dancer.
I’m sorry. The bride and groom seem happy.
That sounds like a late night, and I have work in the morning, so…
Oh, sorry. This wedding just reminds me of my kinda-sorta girlfriend 9,000 miles away.
I’m not moody. I’m fun.
Well, hey, I’m just as much fun as you are.
Okay, fine, what do you suggest?
Once again, I, I’m really not much of a dancer.
I just can’t figure out what happened. I put my left leg in, I took my left leg out, I put my left leg in, and something just snapped.
I did have a great time. Thank you for reminding me it’s okay to have fun once in a while.
And also for breaking the head off the ice swan so I could hold it against my pulled groin.
Well, okay. Again, thank you.
Want to come in, have a cup of tea?
Okay. Well, good night.
Sounds like you had a great night.
Not bad. I had a lot more fun with Amy than I thought I would.
Well, it turns out she really knows how to help a guy loosen up and have a good time. Although, truth be told, my groin’s a little worse for wear. (Sheldon hits him) Ow! Why did you do that?
What?
Penny: Thank you all for this high honour.
All right, I got to go to work. I’ll walk down with you.
You’re a brain scientist. Can you explain to me why a brilliant man likes playing with toy trains?
Aw. So handsome. Like James Bond.
Oh, sweetie, guests don’t normally wear corsages to a wedding. That’s more of a prom thing.
Ames, hi. How was the wedding?
Come in, let’s talk. Do you want a glass of wine?
Okay, I’m sorry, what exactly happened?
Oh, God, did he make a move on you?
Yeah, I’m sure he’ll be okay.
So, um, what are you gonna do? Do you want me to talk to Leonard, let him down easy?
Sheldon: Penny, a moment. We just had Thai food. In that culture, the last morsel is called the krengjai piece, and it is reserved for the most important and valued member of the group.
I’ve seen pictures of your mother, keep eating.
Wait. Uh, which is closer to the new train store in Monrovia, the movie theatre or the Cheesecake Factory?

Oh, well, then I guess it doesn’t matter which one of you drives me. Let’s play a fun guessing game to see who gets to take me. All right, this four-letter word describes either a printer’s type size or a compulsion to eat dirt.
No, Penny, don’t give up, you can get this.
Oh, I’m not buying anything. They’re having a lecture. H-O gauge railroading. Half the size of O-gauge, but twice the fun. Very controversial topic.
I’ll let you know after tonight. Unlike some people, I’m going in with an open mind. Who am I kidding? Of course we all know it’s O-gauge or no gauge.
Howard, I think I can help here. Yes, Bernadette, that’s exactly what he thinks.
Okay, everybody calm down. There is a simple solution here. Raj, take me to the train store, and then I don’t care what you people do.

You don’t know the half of it. It was billed as a lively give-and-take on the merits of model train sizes. But it was actually a set-up to intimidate weak-minded spineless rubes into buying H-O starter sets.
I don’t want to talk about it. But it’s not a spine,I’ll tell you that.
Not my fault. You said there’d be other scientists there my age.
Ha-ha, you have to go to a wedding.
All this years, I’ve been so wrong. The tinier the train, the more concentrated the fun.
Better than James Bond, because he’s tinier.
All aboard! Woo-woo! It’s official. I’m an H-O trainiac.
Leonard. Check it out. I bought an N-gauge locomotive. Half the size of H-O. Look, it fits in my mouth.
I did. How was yours?
What exactly do you mean by that?
To send a message. She is not for you.
Not for you!
Howard: All right, honey, if we’re gonna make the movie, we should go. (Raj stands) This may be hard for you to hear, but when I say honey, I mean my fiancée. (Raj whispers to him) Yeah, well, now it means her.
Fine. But next time, we get a sitter.
Neither of them are close.
Which side do you come down on?
Can you believe grown men sit around and play with toy trains?
First of all, they’re not tricks, they’re illusions. And, secondly, when we get married, they’re all going up in the attic so you can have that closet for clothes.
Well, don’t think of it that way. Once we move in, it’ll be our house.
Why would she move out? It’s her house.
Why not? It’s a great house, plenty of room, and if we have kids, Mom’s there to help. You know, when she tells the Three Little Pigs story, she actually has hair on her chinny-chin-chin.
Wow, someone obviously has some mommy issues.
Don’t listen to her. Go to the movie theatre.
Movie theatre.
I got it! Oh, hi.
Yeah, well, I’m sorry I didn’t run it by you first.
The bugs only come here because you’re their queen! Listen, how about this. Before we make any kind of decision about where we live, we have a trial run. Stay here for a weekend, see what it’s like.
Sure she would. Ma, do you mind if Bernadette stays here this weekend?
See? She’s good with it.
So, dinner went nice.
Only when it’s fatty. Well, don’t be jealous, babe. Someday you’ll get to cut it for me.
Hey, Ma, how about a little privacy?
Relax, it’ll be fine.
Ready for bed?
Oh. Yeah, she sometimes has problems doing her business. Hang on. Ma, give up! Tonight’s not your night!
Come on, take a break! Bernadette needs to brush her teeth!
Problem solved.
Oh, come on, honey. She’s just sitting in there reading a magazine. You can’t see anything. I go in all the time.
And we have splashdown. Wait here, I’m gonna go light a candle. And then we make passionate love.
Morning, Mom.
Yes, it is, and you’re so pretty in the morning.
Oh, wow. So you guys are getting along?
Is there any butter?
Oh.
I don’t need any butter.
Well, I guess I’ll cut these by myself.
Bernadette: It’s okay if he wants to come.
What are you going to get at the train store, Sheldon?
That’s pretty big talk for a man with a closet full of magic tricks at his mother’s house.
Why would I keep clothes at your mother’s house?
Is she moving out?
Hang on. You seriously think I’m going to live with your mother?
I’m not gonna live with your mother. Not now, not ever.
Raj, take me home.
Take me home now.
Hey. I don’t want to fight. I was just surprised when you sprung the whole living-with-your-mom stuff on me.
And your mom would be okay with that?
Yeah. Yeah, I guess. Does your mother always cut your meat for you?
I’m okay, Mrs. Wolowitz.
Oh, God.
Okay.
No. I need to brush my teeth, but your mother’s been in the bathroom for, like, an hour.
No, it’s not. I’m not going in there.
Good morning, handsome.
It’s me.
Your mom and I made you breakfast.
Yeah, I guess. We’re very different people, Howard, so communication’s a little tricky.
It’s butter-flavoured syrup.
He wants butter!
I just told him that!
If you want butter, I’ll get you butter.
Amy: No, I have no interest in model trains, stores that sell them, nor their heartbreaking clientele.
I can’t imagine that would disturb me. Carry on.
Not really, no.
Leonard, please. I don’t need the running commentary.
Yo.
Oh, sure.
I was. Now I’m thinking about what I read. You all right, Leonard? You seem very uncomfortable.
Should I go? I’ve been told sometimes I overstay my welcome.
Well, most recently my gynaecologist.
I’m glad to hear you say that, because I’m having a wonderful time. Hmm, I said the same thing to my gynaecologist.
How was your shower?
Oh, I’m up all night. I’m like a possum. Boy, you were not liked in high school, were you?
Mm-hmm. Dear Leonard, you’re really good at science. Maybe one day you’ll come up with a cure for being a dork.
If it makes you feel any better, the only person who signed my yearbook was my mother.
Dear Amy, self-respect and a hymen are better than friends and fun. Love, Mom.
Well, I had a delightful evening, Leonard. We should do this again sometime.
Glad to hear it. I need someone to accompany me to the wedding of Dr. Moranelli and Dr. Gustufson this Friday. They’re kind of the Brad and Angelina of the primatology department.
I would, but the last wedding we went to was a disaster. He behaved like a child the entire time.
Doesn’t matter. You’re out, he’s in. No date to the prom, two dates to a wedding. Hmm, how times change.
Not without cutting his head open, no. How about making my eyes like Cleopatra?
Perhaps you’re right. My cheekbones and beckoning pelvis already have a certain hello sailor quality to them.
I got you this to give to me.
I never went to my prom. My mom paid my cousin to take me, but he just used the money to buy drugs.
When you’re done copping a feel, that goes on my wrist.
Would you like to dance?
You’re not exactly winning any trophies as a conversationalist, either.
Why shouldn’t they be? They have a feverish night of socially-approved copulation ahead of them. In some cultures, we’d stand outside of their bedroom cheering as they achieved orgasm.
Leonard, you may not have noticed, but I am being a delight here. And you’re not holding up your end of the evening.

I have a kinda-sorta boyfriend who’s playing with a model train right now, you don’t hear me bitching about it. Leonard, a word of advice, moody self-obsession is only attractive in men who can play guitar and are considerably taller than you.
You have any evidence to support that statement?
Really? Are you willing to draw a moustache on your finger as a conversational icebreaker? I am.

We just had a lovely meal, the band is on fire, and you’re sitting next to a beautiful woman wearing whorish makeup. Why don’t we head outon the dance floor and see if I can sweat through these dress shields.
Don’t worry, I’ll lead. (They do the Birdie Song dance)
Howard?
There we go, last floor.
The hokey pokey is a young man’s game.
You’re welcome.
I excel at spatial reasoning, and I had a hunch that the graceful slope of its neck would cradle your genitals nicely.
And again, you’re welcome.
No, thanks. I’m gonna head home.
Good night. (Heads across corridor and knocks on Penny’s door)
Great. Until I accidentally made Leonard fall in love with me.
Wine is one of the reasons I’m in this fix. That and this dang pelvis.
The inevitable, he was lonely and vulnerable from missing his girlfriend, while I was charming, supportive and, let’s face it, in this dress, the perfect combination of Madonna and whore.
No, but it’s only a matter of time. How could I have not seen this coming? Now I’m gonna have to break the little sad sack’s heart.
Oh, Penny, much as I would treasure knowing that the two of us had been defiled by the same man, Leonard just doesn’t get my motor running.
No. I’ll let him have tonight. Then in the morning, I’ll send him an e-mail letting him know this body is never gonna be his wonderland. I mean, frankly, you’ve got a better shot than he does.
Sheldon (entering): Well, you can add Jerry’s Junction to the list of train stores Sheldon Cooper will never set foot in again.
Mrs Wolowitz (off): I don’t know who you’re talking to, but in or out! We don’t need bugs!
Hey, if she’s willing to give the milk away for free, who am I to say no?
Frankly, after all your sleepovers with the little brown boy, a girl is a big relief!
Bernadette! I found the extra head for the Waterpik if you want to use it!
You sure? I just squirted half a brisket outta my teeth!
Oh, I know what that means! Hubba-hubba!
Let me know when you’re done canoodling! Mommy needs a foot rub!
You don’t know that! I just sat down!
She can come in and brush her teeth! I’m not embarrassed!
